{{Infobox Governor |name = Albinus Nance |image = Albinus Nance.jpg |imagesize = 150 px |order1 = 4th |office1 = Governor of Nebraska |term_start1 = January 9, 1879 |term_end1 = January 4, 1883 |lieutenant1 = [[Edmund C. Carns]] |predecessor1 = [[Silas Garber]] |successor1 = [[James W. Dawes]] |office2 = Member of the [[Nebraska Senate]] |term2 = 1875–1878 |birth_date = {{Birth date|1848|3|30}} |death_date = {{Death date and age|1911|12|7|1848|3|30}} |birth_place = |death_place = |party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] |spouse = Sarah White |profession = |religion = }} '''Albinus Roberts Nance''' (March 30, 1848 – December 7, 1911) was an [[Politics of the United States|American politician]]. He served as a soldier during the [[American Civil War]], and as the [[List of Governors of Nebraska|fourth]] [[Governor of Nebraska]]. Nance was born in [[La Fayette, Illinois]] on March 30, 1848. He was born to Dr. Hiram Nance and Sarah (Smith) Nance.White's pg. 2 He was educated in [[Kewanee, Illinois]], until age sixteen.Nance's pp. 140-143 He married Sarah White and they had one child.{{cite web|title=Albinus Nance|url=http://www.nga.org/cms/home/governors/past-governors-bios/page_nebraska/col2-content/main-content-list/title_nance_albinus.html|publisher=National Governors Association|accessdate=16 September 2012}} ==Career== At age sixteen, Nance enlisted with the [[9th Regiment Illinois Volunteer Cavalry|9th Illinois Cavalry]]. Nance fought in the [[American Civil War]], from 1861-1865. He served as a [[Private (rank)|private]] during the war. He fought in the battles of [[Hurricane Creek (Arkansas)|Hurricane Creek]], [[Battle of Guntown|Guntown]], [[Battle of Columbia|Columbia]], [[Battle of Spring Hill|Spring Hill]], [[Battle of Franklin (1864)|Franklin]], and [[Battle of Nashville|Nashville]]. He was slightly wounded, during the [[Battle of Nashville]]. In 1865, after the war was over, Nance became a student at [[Knox College (Illinois)|Knox College]]. In 1870, he was admitted to the bar in [[Illinois]]. ==Political career== Nance moved to Nebraska in 1871 to homestead and practice law, eventually settling in [[Osceola, Nebraska]]. He divided his time between farming and his law practice. He soon gave up farming, for his law practice and large real estate business. In 1874, Nance was nominated by the state [[Republican Party (U.S.)|Republican Party]] to run for the [[Nebraska House of Representatives]]. During his election, in 1875, Nance married Sarah White. He won the election and served as a member of the [[Nebraska Legislature]] from 1875 to 1878, and served as the [[Nebraska Legislature|Speaker of the Nebraska House of Representatives]] from 1877 to 1878. Nance was also a delegate to the [[Republican National Convention]] in 1876. In 1878, while [[Nebraska Legislature|Speaker of the Nebraska House of Representatives]], Nance was elected [[List of Governors of Nebraska|Governor of Nebraska]]. He was only thirty years old at the time of his election, and was known as "the boy governor".Sheldon's pp. 268-269 Nance and his administration were very popular with the people. His administration was described in ''The Public Men of Today'' in 1882, "The distinguishing feature of his administration has been an unassuming but inflexible determination to execute the laws with fidelity to the best interests of the people of Nebraska."[http://genealogytrails.com/neb/governoralbunusnance.htm The Public Men of Today (1882)] Nance was renominated for the governorship, in 1880. He won the election, with an overwhelming majority. He is known for calling in the Nebraska state militia to subdue the strikers in the [[Camp Dump Strike]]; one striker was killed by the militia. ==Death== After being governor, Nance retired to civilian life. He owned large parts of numerous banks. He eventually retired altogether from business life. Nance died in [[Chicago]], on December 7, 1911.Raimo's pg. 893 [[Nance County, Nebraska]] is named after him.Bulletin, Issues 196-201 pg. 197 ==See also== {{Portal|Biography}} * [[List of Governors of Nebraska]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== {{Refbegin}} *White, J. T.; ''"The National cyclopaedia of American biography, Volume 12"'', J. T. White, (1904) *Nance, George Washington; ''"The Nance memorial: a history of the Nance family in general, but more particularly of Clement Nance, of Pittsylvania County, Virginia, and descendants, containing historical and biographical records with family lineage"'', J. E. Burke & co., printers, (1904) *Sheldon, Addison Erwin; ''"History and stories of Nebraska"'', University Publishing Co., (1919) *Raimo, John; ''"Biographical directory of the governors of the United States, 1789-1978, Volume 3"'', Meckler Books, (1978) *Geological Survey (U.S.); ''"Bulletin, Issues 196-201"'', G.P.O., (1902) {{Refend}} ==External links== *{{Cite web |title=The Political Graveyard |work=Nance, Albinus |url=http://politicalgraveyard.com/bio/naar-nary.html#RGQ18J0QZ |accessdate=January 3, 2006 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20060105010206/http://politicalgraveyard.com/bio/naar-nary.html| archivedate= 5 January 2006 | deadurl= no}} *[http://www.nebraskahistory.org/lib-arch/research/public/state_governors/nance.pdf Albinus Nance papers] at the [[Nebraska State Historical Society]]. Retrieved on June 22, 2009. *{{Cite web|title=NEGenWeb Project |work=ALBINUS NANCE |url=http://www.rootsweb.com/~neresour/OLLibrary/pbal/pages/balc0028.htm |accessdate=January 3, 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050120192402/http://www.rootsweb.com/~neresour/OLLibrary/pbal/pages/balc0028.htm |archivedate=January 20, 2005 }} *{{Cite web |title=Nebraska...Our Towns |url=http://www.casde.unl.edu/history/counties/polk/osceola/ |accessdate=May 6, 2009 }} *{{Cite web |title=City of Osceola|url= http://www.osceolanebraska.com/ |accessdate=May 6, 2009 }} *{{Find a Grave|12839|accessdate=2008-09-27}}
